abstracts.cdata!:
The Balochistan Education Support
            Project for Pakistan received a moderately satisfactory
            outcome rating with high risk to development outcome. The
            Bank received a satisfactory rating for their performance
            while the Borrower received a moderately satisfactory
            rating. Three restructurings took place throughout the
            course of this project. The first restructuring extended the
            project closing date 18 months to allow completion of
            construction activities under Component 1 of the Project.
            The second restructuring (i) Extended the project closing
            date another two years to allow for completion of
            construction of functional community schools under Component
            1 and (ii) Reallocation of unallocated expenditure category
            to finance Community Implementation Partner contracts for
            extension period, to meet Balochistan Education Foundation
            (BEF) equipment and operational expenses during extension
            period, and to provide additional resources for school
            construction. The third restructuring reallocated funds
            originally allocated for the construction of a BEF office to
            cover expenses for office equipment for BEF staff (including
            monitoring equipment), a refresher teacher training course
            for community school teachers, and overdrawn Category 4
            expenditure on support to construction of community schools.
            The following lessons were drawn from this project: (1) It
            is very important that the public sector commitment and
            ownership for the implementation and successful completion
            of any project are efficient. (2) The PECs when migrate or
            their children graduate, they have to quit the membership of
            the PEC. The PECs should be imparted with regular training
            every year or every second or third year. (3) In retaining
            children and teachers attendance, and increasing children
            enrollment and decreasing dropouts, community active
            participation is important. (4) Public sector institutions
            capacity to measure average annual increase in learning
            achievement in Language and Mathematics in Schools is weak.
            This needs to be built within institution, which deal with
            the education sector. (5) To retain teachers at Community
            Schools, their salaries need to be at the minimum equivalent
            to the minimum wage rate. (6) Capacity development support
            is crucial for ensuring timely and effective implementation
            of projects in provinces and regions that have limited
            public sector capacity, weak private sector presence and
            have deteriorating law and order situation. (7) Community
            School construction should be undertaken through
            professional engineering contractors under the supervision
            of PECs. (8) Early Childhood Education should be made a part
            of primary school teacher training. (9) Most importantly,
            the community school establishment design is far time and
            cost effective. The province is suffering from and alarming
            access issue. Education Department of Balochistan should
            adopt this design to ensure access throughout Balochistan.
